awd_titl_txt: Sustainable Agriculture and Green Energy Project
awd_abstract_narration: SAGE (Sustainable Agriculture and Green Energy) is a two-year Advanced Technology Education project that is laying the foundation for focused rural technician education and training in sustainability fields that include agriculture and renewable energy/energy efficiency  under an umbrella of sustainable green education.  Greenfield Community College (GCC) is innovating in technical education for rural students in the Western Massachusetts region through enhanced curriculum and infrastructure that support its Farm and Food Systems (FFS) and Renewable Energy/Energy Efficiency (RE/EE) degree option programs. These enhancements, along with the many existing relationships between GCC and regional agricultural and energy employers, are serving as a fulcrum for improving technical education and for solidifying sustainability career pathways.  SAGE is serving as the foundation for bridging the traditional separation of vocational training and academic learning in STEM-based sustainability education.  A new 4-credit Greenhouse Management course and curricular revisions across STEM course offerings are impacting students in both the Farm and Food Systems (FFS) and Renewable Energy/Energy Efficiency (RE/EE) degree options. New curricula feature hands-on learning opportunities utilizing innovative infrastructure, including Greenhouse External and Internal Solar Thermal Collection Units, Permaculture Rainwater Harvesting System, and a standalone 500W Photovoltaic System.  A robust internship experience links GCC students with regional employers in agriculture and renewable energy/energy efficiency for workplace-based skill attainment that lead to employment opportunities. Ongoing engagement with secondary and four-year institutions through 2 + 2 + 2 articulations is helping to improve student preparation in the technical education pipeline.

The SAGE Project – Sustainable Agriculture & Green Energy at Greenfield Community College

Where science, civic responsibility and workforce development meet.

Greenfield Community College serves mostly rural, modest-income counties in Western Massachusetts. Enrollment is approximately 2,000 ‘full-time equivalent’ students. The college is well known for its strong transfer rate and successful career pathway programs such as engineering, renewable energy, nursing, advanced manufacturing, and entrepreneurship. Since its founding in 1962, GCC has built its programs and student success through extensive collaboration with the community members, companies, organizations and K-12 public schools.

The SAGE project at Greenfield Community College brings together related goals of sustainable economic development, technical workforce training, scientific education and civic engagement. The region has a rich tradition of innovative small businesses offering forward-thinking green technologies and services. Our work has leveraged extensive funds from private businesses, foundations, public grants, and government agencies to support students in acquiring skills and jobs with those businesses. These fields include agriculture, food systems, high performance buildings, renewable energy, energy efficiency and environmental science. Successful careers require that students have fundamental scientific understanding and practical, applied skills. Through the ATE project, GCC has built a teaching model that combines traditional lab science with technical skill building through expanded hands-on learning opportunities, including on-the-job internships.

Since 2014, 154 students in SAGE majors have been directly served by project. Technical fields like agriculture, energy, and environmental science are rapidly changing and today’s workforce looks very different from even five years ago. We rely on partnership with 90 regional businesses and organizations to keep us up-to-date on the state of their industries and employer needs. Those partners also provide guest speakers, course instructors, internship sites and job hires. Internships represent the most extensive and valuable hands-on learning we can offer in a two-year academic program.

Expansion of our internship program is a major accomplishment funded by this ATE Project grant. From 2014-2017, the annual number of SAGE student interns grew from 27, to 30, to 53. Last year three-quarters of SAGE students pursued an internship averaging 3 credits (145 hours). A successful community college internship program begins with willing businesses and a college staff person to coordinate, but requires much more. It requires funding to pay for students’ time, since most cannot afford an unpaid internship. Many businesses in our region have 10 or fewer employees and cannot fund an intern. Under the guidance of our Internship Coordinator – a position partially funded by this ATE grant – many employers received funds from the Mass Clean Energy Center (CEC). Between 2014-17, the CEC paid SAGE interns $114,800 to work at area businesses. Several other grant funds provide intern stipends, including awards from the USDA, Rural Community College Alliance, and the Massachusetts Dept. of High Education STEM Starter initiative. For students with low or modest income, each aspect of this internship model is essential. After three years, GCC has a robust, sustainable internship program that serves students, local businesses and the community college mission.

Strong internships happen because students move through an educational program that prepares them well. The SAGE model relies upon many levels of hands-on learning to accomplish that. In laboratory courses students gain a solid scientific foundation and apply quantitative skills. With our enhanced on-campus teaching infrastructure, faculty have revised and developed new courses to teach science geared toward SAGE fields. This ATE grant provided $26,000 that leveraged an additional $100,000 in funding to build out a one-acre, multi-use Outdoor Learning Laboratory (OLL). Prior to the ATE project, our energy students had access to our LEED Gold certified building systems, geothermal wells, wood pellet boilers, solar thermal system, 81 KW photovoltaic array and near-net-zero greenhouse. Our farm and food systems students had designed and installed a diverse permaculture garden. With the ATE Project, we added state-of-the-art energy conservation technology to the greenhouse. We completed the OLL that integrates wetland ecology, erosion and water management, botanical garden collections, raised bed vegetable production, habitat restoration and pollinator ecology. We are expanding the teaching farm on campus. SAGE students are part of all these projects. The on-campus infrastructure allows us to prepare students rigorously for internships and technical careers.

The ATE grant has provided essential support for building both the academic model for experiential technical education and the infrastructure to deliver it. With three years of ATE funding, and other resources leveraged by that funding, GCC has created a vibrant hands-on learning environment for students in SAGE programs, other science programs, and even outside of STEM. The Project has greatly advanced our capacity to respond to emerging workforce and student needs for our regional economy. It has positioned our community college as a leader and resource. The SAGE initiative remains vibrant and will continue to grow and serve the needs of our region.
